newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland mulls three sell-offs this month.
newsitem.headline: Poland mulls three sell-offs this month.

text.p: Poland could sell brewer Zaklady Piwowarskie w Lezajsku SA (Lezajsk) in the next two weeks and receive a concrete offer for its newsstand chain Ruch SA by this week's end, a deputy treasury ministry said on Monday.
Wieslaw Kaczmarek said a third firm, rolling stock maker Pafawag SA, could be sold by January 15.

"It (the sale) could happen this week or next week," Kaczmarek told Reuters on the planned sale of 75 percent of Lezajsk to one of two unnamed domestic investors with which the ministry has said it was in talks.
The ministry has said it was eager to seal the Lezajsk deal quickly to start the brewer's necessary restructuring.
According to 1994 data, the most recent figures available, the brewer netted 90,000 zlotys on sales of 71.7 million.
Kaczmarek also said France's Hachette Distribution Services might make a firm financial offer to buy Ruch by December 13.
"They have exclusivity rights until December 13 so it's hard to say how it will turn out," Kaczmarek said.
Kaczmarek has said that if talks with Hachette failed, the ministry, which has picked Hachette for exclusive negotiations, might renew talks with other bidders or announce a new tender.

Kaczmarek also said on Monday that the ministry had lengthened until January 15 the negotiation period concerning Adtranz's tentative agreement with Poland to buy rolling stock maker Pafawag SA. Adtranz, a joint venture of ABB Group and Daimler-Benz AG, had said it would buy Pafawag if Polish State Railways (PKP) confirmed by November's end it would place orders with Pafawag.
Late in the month PKP said it would buy 50 state-of-the-art locomotives from Pafawag.
Adtranz has said it would pay $3.7 million for a 75 percent stake in the ailing Pafawag and invest $28.1 million over the next six years.
Kaczmarek said the finalization of Pafawag's sale now rested with PKP and the transport ministry.
